data.name: Gaussian primes
data.description: ## Gaussian integers > A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. Consider the set of complex numbers z = x + iy with integer coefficients x and y. They are called Gaussian integers. The norm of Gaussian integer is a non-negative integer defined by N(x + iy) = x2 + y2. The multiplication of Gaussian integers is defined in a usual way: (x1 + iy1) (x2 + iy2) = (x1x2 − y1y2) + i (x1y2 + x2y1). E. g., (1 + i) (2 − 3i) = (2 + 3) + i (−3 + 2) = 5 − i. One may check that the norm of the product equals to the product of norms of factors. In the example above N(1 + i) = 12 + 12 = 2, N(2 − 3i) = 22 + (−3)2 = 13 and N(5 − i) = 52 + (−1)2 = 26 = 2 · 13. It appears that the notion of primality can be extended to Gaussian integers. Gaussian integer z is called Gaussian prime if its norm is greater than 1 and it has no divisors with norms distinct from 1 and N(z). As we saw above, 5 − i is not a Gaussian prime, because it has non-trivial divisors 1 + i and 2 − 3i. On contrary, one can check that 1 + i and 2 − 3i are Gaussian primes. Further, 2 and 5 are (rational) primes, but not Gaussian ones: 2 = (1 + i) (1 − i), 5 = (2 − i) (2 + i). But primes 3 and 7 appears to be Gaussian primes too. More examples. ## Task Your task in this kata is to check, whether a given Gaussian integer is Gaussian prime or not. Use preloaded data type ```haskell data Gaussian = Gaussian {realPart :: Integer, imagPart :: Integer} -- with norm norm :: Gaussian -> Integer norm (Gaussian x y) = x * x + y * y ``` ```javascript new Gaussian(x, y) .multiply(smth) .add(smth) .subtract(smth) .norm() ```
